More Notes: Estimates suggest that a 1°C increase in the annual mean temperature would result in a worldwide increase in obese adults of 79.7 million, or 12.3%.

The analysis estimates marginal effect of temperature on obesity, but the value is not provided on this page.  The marginal effect is dependent on whether short-run or long-run models are used.
Marginal effect of warming is significantly positive for most countries (except 21 tropical countries with mean temperature > 27°C). 0 is a placeholder as no numeric value is provided
Marginal effect of warming is a reducing effect. 0 is a placeholder as no numeric value is provided

Effect of 1°C increase in annual mean temperature on male obesity rate, based on data up to 2016.
Effect of 1°C increase in annual mean temperature on female obesity rate, estimated as one-third smaller than male obesity rate, based on data up to 2016.
Increase in female obesity rate due to global warming. Data goes up to 2016, so reporting effect by that year.
Estimate suggests that more days with temperatures under 9 ◦C would reduce obesity (compared to the 12–15 ◦C bin). However, more days with temperatures above 15 ◦C would increase obesity.
Warming of low-temperature seasons (i.e., seasons 1 and 2) has a negligible effect on obesity.
Warming of high-temperature seasons (i.e., seasons 3 and 4) significantly increases obesity.
Estimated visually from Figure 10, represents the increase in obesity rate (percentage) corresponding to an increase from 0 to 10 months with positive temperature shocks

Long-run model estimates a threshold temperature of 18.5°C, above which obesity rate decreases. The response function has been normalized to start from zero. This '0' reflects normalization, actual impact varies.

Short-run model estimates a threshold temperature of 27.3°C, above which obesity rate decreases. The response function has been normalized to start from zero. This '0' reflects normalization, actual impact varies. See also Fig 3 and 4 for details.
